bibl.title: Letter from Patrick J. Hurley to Morris Sheppard, January 29, 1930

div1.p: Secretary of War Hurley summarizes Ames' service record, concluding that Ames does not merit inclusion in the yellow fever roll of honor. He suggests that Sheppard turn over any additional official papers to the War Department.

div1.head: Letter from Patrick J. Hurley to Morris Sheppard, January 29, 1930
div1.opener:
From Mrs Ames
COPY
WAR DEPARTMENT
Washington
January 29, 1930.
Honorable Morris Sheppard,
United States Senate.
Dear Senator Sheppard:
div1.p:
I again refer to your letter of December 31,
1929, receipt of which has heretofore been acknowledged, suggest-
ing that there be added to the record of service of Dr. Roger P.
Ames, assistant surgeon, United States Army, which was furnished
you by the War Department on December 27, 1929, a record of his
service in Cuba in connection with yellow fever experiments con-
ducted by the yellow fever board under the direction of Major Wal-
ter Reed in 1900-1901.

For your convenience I have embodied the in-
formation furnished you on December 27, 1929, in the following
statement which contains such additional information as the re-
cords of the War Department afford:

It is shown by the official records that Roger
P. Ames served under contract as acting assistant surgeon, U. S.
Army, from May 14, 1898, to November 30, 1898, when his contract
was annulled. He again entered into contract as acting assistant
surgeon April 15, 1899, and his contract was annulled April 26,
1901, in order that he might accept a volunteer commission as cap-
tain and assistant surgeon.

During his service under this latter contract,
while stationed at Camp Lazear, the yellow fever experimental camp
established in Cuba by the Yellow Fever Board, he performed duties
of a purely administrative character, and as one of the medical
officers on duty at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, he had professional
charge of experimental cases of yellow fever, but there has not
been found in the War Department or in the published papers of the
Yellow Fever Board (Senate Documents 822, 61st Congress, 3d Session.
Serial No. 5919) any evidence to show that Dr. Ames took part in
the actual experiments of the Board, and it is deemed proper to add
that his service was not of such a character as to warrant the en-
try of his name on the Roll of Honor provided for in Act Public
No. 858, 70th Congress, approved February 28, 1929, an act to recog-
nize the high public service rendered by Major Walter Reed and those
associated with him in the discovery of the cause and means of trans-
mission of yellow fever.

It is suggested if the official papers referred
to in your letter of December 31, 1929, afford any additional evi-
dence of the service of Dr. Roger P. Ames that they be turned over
to the War Department where they would be available at any time in
the future that it might be desired to furnish a complete record
of the service of Dr. Ames.

In addition to the services as contract surgeon
above cited Roger P. Ames was appointed major and surgeon of volun-
teers January 6, 1902, and was honorably discharged from service
February 1, 1903, a major and surgeon of volunteers. He again en-
tered into contract as acting assistant surgeon February 27, 1903,
and his contract was annulled March 15, 1907.

closer.signed:
Patrick J. Hurley (S)
Secretary of War
